text: I've been flying around the world this
year covering pro-democracy street
protests in places like Egypt Morocco
bak rain but to cover the latest of
these uprisings it turned out to be a
lot easier I just took the subway to the
Wall Street financial district I found
hundreds of protesters have taken over a
square right in the financial district
they come from all kinds of backgrounds
they seem to have all kinds of diverse
demands in some way there's a little bit
of an echo of the Tea Party although
these folks are mostly on the left the
protesters seemed remarkably organized
in some ways they have a little kitchen
area with food they have a media area
they have a welcome reception area when
I talk to protesters and ask them what
exactly they wanted I heard all kinds of
different answers the reason I'm here is
because I I don't know I don't believe
in the the current
social political economic structure I am
here for accountability I want somebody
to be held accountable for the
corruptness that's going on and in the
economy and overseas I want somebody to
be held accountable opt out their office
in handcuffs so we're starting movement
here in New York I think it's great one
woman I spoke with who works in the wall
street area said she'd been passing the
protest every day and finally somebody
told her join in I was I'm from the 60s
when we protested the war and everything
was going on then ass college campuses
why is the youth of today so silent some
of the protesters have
anti-globalization and anti-capitalism
tinge to them that I don't share at all
I frankly think that banks and
corporations have tended to raise our
standard of living but I do agree with
them that in recent years the banks have
pretty much gotten away with murder and
since those protesters don't have a
clear agenda or manifesto let me offer
some help one remedy is a financial
transaction tax this is something that
was named after a american nobel
prize-winning economist james tobin the
idea is to have a tiny tax on every
financial transaction as a way not only
of raising sorely needed money but also
to dampen speculation Europe is moving
in that direction but the Obama
administration has resisted that effort
it's time for a financial transaction
tax another suggestion eliminate the
carried interest loophole this is one of
the most egregious tax loopholes there
is it allows some of the wealthiest
Americans involved in hedge funds and
private equity for example to pay much
lower tax rates than average Americans
with much much lower incomes we also
need to explore whether it's time to
eliminate the tax break for capital
gains sure there are reason is to have a
lower tax rate for capital gains because
we want to encourage investment but at
this point that has been so manipulated
and so many very very wealthy people are
benefiting from it that it does feed a
sense of unfairness that people earning
a wonderful living through their
investment should be paying
much lower rates than people earning a
living through their sweat another step
forward is to increase financial
regulation on banks to try to prevent
the kind of system whereby banks take
risks and profit from them but when
those risks go badly the down side is
socialized we don't want to privatize
the profits and socialize the risk and
that's the system that we've had now so
as the wall street protests gain
traction and as they bubble up around
the country i offer these suggestions to
those protestors is a way of translating
their amorphous frustration into a
tangible program of changes that might
make our financial system more
accountable and more equitable
you
